Class Detail
AV.Promise(fn)
A Promise is returned by async methods as a hook to provide callbacks to be called when the async task is fulfilled.

Typical usage would be like:

   query.find().then(function(results) {
     results[0].set("foo", "bar");
     return results[0].saveAsync();
   }).then(function(result) {
     console.log("Updated " + result.id);
   });

Another example:

   var promise = new AV.Promise(function(resolve, reject) {
     resolve(42);
   });
   promise.then(function(value){
     console.log(value);
   }).catch(function(error){
     console.error(error);
   });

Parameters:
{Function} fn
An optional function with two arguments resolve and reject.The first argument fulfills the promise, the second argument rejects it. We can call these functions, once our operation is completed.
See:
AV.Promise.prototype.then

<static> {AV.Promise} AV.Promise.race(promises)
Returns a promise that resolves or rejects as soon as one of the promises in the iterable resolves or rejects, with the value or reason from that promise.Returns a new promise that is fulfilled when one of the input promises. For example: 
  var p1 = AV.Promise.as(1);
  var p2 = AV.Promise.as(2);
  var p3 = AV.Promise.as(3);

  AV.Promise.race(p1, p2, p3).then(function(result) {
    console.log(result);  // prints 1
  });
The input promises can also be specified as an array: 
  var promises = [p1, p2, p3];
  AV.Promise.when(promises).then(function(result) {
    console.log(result);  // prints 1
  });
Parameters:
{Array} promises
a list of promises to wait for.
Returns:
{AV.Promise} the new promise.
reject(error)
Marks this promise as fulfilled, firing any callbacks waiting on it.
Parameters:
{Object} error
the error to pass to the callbacks.
resolve(result)
Marks this promise as fulfilled, firing any callbacks waiting on it.
Parameters:
{Object} result
the result to pass to the callbacks.
{AV.Promise} then(resolvedCallback, rejectedCallback)
Adds callbacks to be called when this promise is fulfilled. Returns a new Promise that will be fulfilled when the callback is complete. It allows chaining. If the callback itself returns a Promise, then the one returned by "then" will not be fulfilled until that one returned by the callback is fulfilled.
Parameters:
{Function} resolvedCallback
Function that is called when this Promise is resolved. Once the callback is complete, then the Promise returned by "then" will also be fulfilled.
{Function} rejectedCallback
Function that is called when this Promise is rejected with an error. Once the callback is complete, then the promise returned by "then" with be resolved successfully. If rejectedCallback is null, or it returns a rejected Promise, then the Promise returned by "then" will be rejected with that error.
Returns:
{AV.Promise} A new Promise that will be fulfilled after this Promise is fulfilled and either callback has completed. If the callback returned a Promise, then this Promise will not be fulfilled until that one is.
try()
Alias of AV.Promise.prototype.done
See:
AV.Promise#done
<static> {AV.Promise} AV.Promise.when(promises)
Returns a new promise that is fulfilled when all of the input promises are resolved. If any promise in the list fails, then the returned promise will fail with the last error. If they all succeed, then the returned promise will succeed, with the results being the results of all the input promises. For example: 
  var p1 = AV.Promise.as(1);
  var p2 = AV.Promise.as(2);
  var p3 = AV.Promise.as(3);

  AV.Promise.when(p1, p2, p3).then(function(r1, r2, r3) {
    console.log(r1);  // prints 1
    console.log(r2);  // prints 2
    console.log(r3);  // prints 3
  });
The input promises can also be specified as an array: 
  var promises = [p1, p2, p3];
  AV.Promise.when(promises).then(function(r1, r2, r3) {
    console.log(r1);  // prints 1
    console.log(r2);  // prints 2
    console.log(r3);  // prints 3
  });
Parameters:
{Array} promises
a list of promises to wait for.
Returns:
{AV.Promise} the new promise.
